channel.title: Double Star Program on Astronomy
channel.description: Recent content in Double Star Program on Astronomy

item.title: Alpha Piscium
item.description:
Alpha Piscium

Star 7 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Alpha Piscium
Seeing: G
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.37
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 200x
Date: 10-23-25
Time: 10:19pm EST
Est. P.A.: N/A see notes.

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Alpha Piscium is white in color.

Additional Notes

With my very best and highest magnification EP I could not split this pair. I know I was on target however since A Piscium is easy to find in the constellation. I also confirmed the EP view in Stellarium.

item.title: Gamma Andromedae
item.description:
Gamma Andromedae

Star 8 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Gamma Andromedae
Seeing: G
Transparency: 4+
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.37
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 144x
Date: 10-23-25
Time: 10:50pm EST
Est. P.A.: 75 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very nice pair! The primary is golden and quite large in size. The secondary is blue-white. Maybe a tad more blue than white. The secondary is also quite dimmer.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Gamma Ceti
item.description:
Gamma Ceti

Star 11 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Gamma Ceti
Seeing: G
Transparency: 4+
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.37
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 200x
Date: 10-23-25
Time: 11:52pm EST
Est. P.A.: N/A see notes

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Dull white star.

Additional Notes

Cannot split this with the best scope and EP pairing I have.

item.title: Iota Trianguli
item.description:
Iota Trianguli

Star 9 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Iota Trianguli
Seeing: G
Transparency: 4+
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.37
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 144x
Date: 10-23-25
Time: 11:05pm EST
Est. P.A.: 75 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Primary is slightly yellow and secondary is pale white. The secondary only came into focus in calm atmosphere

Additional Notes

Very close pair and I consulted star charts to comfirm patterns of nearby stars.

item.title: Zeta Piscium
item.description:
Zeta Piscium

Star 4 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Zeta Piscium
Seeing: G
Transparency: 4+
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.37
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 144x
Date: 10-23-25
Time: 11:23pm EST
Est. P.A.: 45 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Easy to split with a 25mm EP. Both are similar in color - white. Primary is visually larger and brighter

Additional Notes

Had to star hop again to find surrounding pentagon pattern of stars with Zeta Pisces in the middle.

item.title: 65 Piscium
item.description:
65 Piscium

Star 2 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: 65 Piscium
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.36, -85.33
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 144x
Date: 10-19-2025
Time: 9:56pm EST
Est. P.A.: 130 deg or 310 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Another pair visually the same in magnitude, size, and color which is blue.

Additional Notes

Couldn’t determine which is primary so two estimated PA are given.

item.title: Gamma Arietis
item.description:
Gamma Arietis

Star 5 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Gamma Arietis
Seeing: G
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.36, -85.33
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 144x
Date: 10-19-2025
Time: 9:18pm EST
Est. P.A.: 10 deg or 100 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Visually both stars are same in size and color. Both are white.

Additional Notes

Can’t tell which is primary so two estimated PA are supplied.

item.title: Lambda Arietis
item.description:
Lambda Arietis

Star 6 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Lambda Arietis
Seeing: G
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.36, -85.33
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 52x
Date: 10-19-2025
Time: 9:34pm EST
Est. P.A.: 45 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Primary is larger and brighter by far. It shinesa brilliant white. Easy to split with fairly low magnification. Secondary looks a bit yellow but very dim.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Beta Cephei
item.description:
Beta Cephei

Star 92 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Beta Cephei
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102
Power:
Date: 10-15-2025
Time: 9:45pm EST
Est. P.A.: 240 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Seeing dropped a bit and Beta Ceph B was only visible in calm atmosphere. Color of the primary is buish-white. Noticable size and magnitude difference in teh pair.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Delta Cephei
item.description:
Delta Cephei

Star 97 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Delta Cephei
Seeing: E
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 144x
Date: 10-15-25
Time: 9:33om EST
Est. P.A.: 190 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Could see this pair as a single star with the naked eye. In the EP easily split with Delta Ceph A being brighter and a dull yellow. The “B” star is white.

item.title: Epsilon Pegasi
item.description:
Epsilon Pegasi

Star 94 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Epsilon Pegasi
Seeing: E
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 144x
Date: 10-15-25
Time: 8:42pm EST
Est. P.A.: 320 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Ep. Pegasus A (Enif) is a brassy, yellow color. It’s secondary is much dimmer but because of the 145 arcsecond delay can be overlooked as a pair.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Xi Cephei
item.description:
Xi Cephei

Star 95 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Xi Cephei

Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32

Xi Ceph A appears twice as bright and approximately three times bigger than Xi Ceph B. Both are white in color.

item.title: Zeta Aquarii
item.description:
Zeta Aquarii

Star 96 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Zeta Aquarii
Seeing: E
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 5
Date: 10-15-25
Time: 9:02pm EST
Est. P.A.: 350 deg or 160 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The pair is the same magnitude and size to the eye. In the EP at this magnification there is a haze around the pair. Both are dull white.

item.title: 1 Camelopardalis
item.description:
1 Camelopardalis

Star 16 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: 1 Camelopardalis
Seeing: (1-10, 10 being perfect)
Transparency: (Limiting magnitude)
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: (Telescope/binoculars used)
Power: (Magnification used)
Date: (YYYY-MM-DD)
Time: (Local time)
Est. P.A.: (Estimated position angle)

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Record your visual impression of the double star here. Note the colors of each component, the contrast between them, and any interesting features.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Nu Scorpii
item.description:
Nu Scorpii

Star 65 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Nu Scorpii
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 30.20, -103.25
Instrument: 750/150mm Orion Starblast 6
Power: 83x
Date: 7-27-2025
Time: 1:05am CST
Est. P.A.: 350 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Primary is noticeably larger and brighter. Both appear white although the secondary may be shifting color a bit in the atmosphere.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Beta Scorpii
item.description:
Beta Scorpii

Star 63 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Beta Scorpii
Seeing: G
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 30.20, -103.25
Instrument: 750/150mm Orion Starblast 6
Power: 83x
Date: 7-26-2025
Time: 12:09pm CST
Est. P.A.: 30 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Primary is cool white and the secondary is bluer in color. Secondary is also significantly smaller and dimmer.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Mu Draconis
item.description:
Mu Draconis

Star 68 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Mu Draconis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 30.20, -103.25
Instrument: 750/150mm Orion Starblast 6
Power: 115x
Date: 7-26-2025
Time: 12:38pm CST
Est. P.A.: 190 deg or 5 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very difficult to split. The pair is also very similar in size and color. Can’t visually tell which is primary.

Additional Notes

Two estimated PAs because I couldn’t visually tell which is the primary star.

item.title: Otto Struve 525
item.description:
Otto Struve 525

Star 83 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Otto Struve 525
Seeing: E
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: 750/150mm
Power: 83x
Date: 7-26-2025
Time: 1:33am CST
Est. P.A.: 350 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Pair is widely separated and differ in color. The primary is golden and the secondary blue. Neither being too brilliant. Primary is obviously larger.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.description:

Great pair with good separation. Both are slightly yellow in color. The secondary star is distinctly smaller.

item.title: 70 Ophiuchi
item.description:
70 Ophiuchi

Star 78 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: 70 Ophiuchi
Seeing: G
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 30.20, -103.25
Instrument: 750/150mm Orion Starblast 6
Power: 83
Date: 2025-07-25
Time: 12:33pm CST
Est. P.A.: 130 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A yellow pair set in the Milky Way. The secondary is about half the size of the primary. Each shines brilliantly.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: 95 Herculis
item.description:
95 Herculis

Star 77 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: 95 Herculis
Seeing: E
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 30.20, -103.25
Instrument: 750/150mm Orion Starblast 6
Power: 83x
Date: 7-25-25
Time: 1:32pm CST
Est. P.A.: 260 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A blue and yellow pair. Neither extremely so, though. Roughly equal in size and magnitude. The blue star appears to be the primary.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Delta Herculis
item.description:
Delta Herculis

Star 70 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Delta Herculis
Seeing: E
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 30.20, -103.25
Instrument: 750/150mm Orion Starblast 6
Power: 83x
Date: 2025-07-25
Time: 1:07pm CST
Est. P.A.: 285 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Surrounding starfield is evenly distributed. Both stars appear white. The primary is so much brighter that the secondary can be hidden in the shine of the primary.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Omicron Ophiuchi
item.description:
Omicron Ophiuchi

Star 72 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Omicron Ophiuchi
Seeing: G
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 30.20, -103.25
Instrument: 750/150mm Orion Starblast 6
Power: 83x
Date: 2025-07-25
Time: 12:16pm CST
Est. P.A.: 350 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The primary is obviuosly larger in size and magnitude with the secondary being less than half the size of the primary. The primary is yellow but not brilliant. The secondary is blue.

item.title: Eta Cassiopeiae
item.description:
Eta Cassiopeiae

Star 1 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Eta Cassiopeiae
Seeing: G
Transparency: 3+
Lat/Lon: 34.12, -86.22
Instrument: 750/150mm Orion Starblast 6
Power: 83x
Date: 10-12-24
Time: 8:55pm EST
Est. P.A.: 340 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The primary star looked as though the color shifted at times due to an instable atmosphere. The star presented mostly white while the secondary was definitely gold. The secondary is much smaller and dimmer than primary.

item.title: Zeta Lyrae
item.description:

Star 80 of 100

Bright pair easily separated at a low power. White in color.

item.title: 61 Cygni
item.description:
61 Cygni

Star 91 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: 61 Cygni
Seeing: G
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.12, -85.33
Instrument: 1300/102 Orion Apex Maksutov
Power: 144x
Date: 8-20-24
Time: 10:21pm EST
Est. P.A.: 155 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

This pair stands out noticeably from the background stars eventhough it is not the brightest pair I’ve observed. Both are golden and apparent size is similar.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Alpha Capricornus
item.description:
Alpha Capricornus

Star 88 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Alpha Capricornus
Seeing: G
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.12, -85.33
Instrument: 1000/102mm Orion Refractor
Power: 40x
Date: 8-20-24
Time: 10:41pm EST
Est. P.A.: 290 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Another golden pair. Their separation is so far I thought Alpha 2 was the primary because of a very faint star near that one in the EP. The true pair is just very far apart.

item.title: Beta Capricornus
item.description:
Beta Capricornus

Star 89 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Beta Capricornus
Seeing: G
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.12, -85.33
Instrument: 1000/102mm Orion Refractor
Power: 40x
Date: 8-20-24
Time: 10:55pm EST
Est. P.A.: 280 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Wide separation but different colors. The primary is easily viewed as larger and gold. The secondary is cooler blue.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Beta Cygni
item.description:
Beta Cygni

Star 85 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Beta Cygni
Seeing: G
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.12, -85.33
Instrument: 1000/102mm Orion Refractor
Power: 40x
Date: 8-20-24
Time: 9:42pm EST
Est. P.A.: 80 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

This is a wonderful pair! Alberio is clearly the larger of the pair and golden. It’s secondary is also bright and colored blue.

Additional Notes

Used an older refractor donated to the club which still performed well.

item.title: 16/17 Draconis
item.description:
16/17 Draconis

Star 67 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: 16/17 Draconis
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.12, -85.33
Instrument: 1300/102 Orion Apex Maksutov
Power: 144x
Date: 6-24-24
Time: 11:06pm EST
Est. P.A.: 100 deg and 185 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Can distinguish the magnitude difference well. The primary pair is tight but is noticeably split. Visually the three stars are similar in color.

Additional Notes

Really cool group on the EP. Two PAs measured since this group is three stars.

item.title: 40/41 Draconis
item.description:
40/41 Draconis

Star 76 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: 40/41 Draconis
Seeing: E
Transparency: 5+
Lat/Lon: 35.12, -85.33
Instrument: 1300/102 Orion Apex Maksutov
Power: 144x
Date: 6-24-24
Time: 10:28pm EST
Est. P.A.: 55 deg or 240 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Similar in magnitude and size. Both are also visually white in color

Additional Notes

Another easy pair to split. Seeing is very good so the stars are crisp points. Was difficult to determin primary so I took two measurements of the PA.

item.title: Alpha Herculis
item.description:
Alpha Herculis

Star 69 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Alpha Herculis

Golden pair in Hercules. Distinctly golden. While still very close at this power, the stars are still split.

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Psi Draconis
item.description:
Psi Draconis

Star 75 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Psi Draconis

item.title: Struve 1999
item.description:
Struve 1999

Star 62 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Struve 1999
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 34.63, -85.44
Instrument: 750/150mm Orion Starblast 6
Power: 83x
Date: 5-30-24
Time: 12:09am EST
Est. P.A.: 95 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Struve 1999 pair is equal in size and magnitude. Both stars are a little golden

Additional Notes

See the comments for Xi Scorpii. Struve 1999 and that pair can be see in the same FOV.

item.title: Xi Scorpii
item.description:
Xi Scorpii

Star 61 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Xi Scorpii
Seeing: E
Transparency: 6

Power: 83x

Est. P.A.: 45 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

XI Scorpii primary is bright and yellow. Much larger than the secondary too.

Additional Notes

This pair and Struve 1999 is in the same FOV! Definitely one to show at star parties.

item.title: Delta Corvi
item.description:
Delta Corvi

Star 45 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Delta Corvi
Seeing: G
Transparency: 3
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: 750/150mm Orion Starblast 6
Power: 75x
Date: 5-28-24
Time: 10:16pm EST

Visual Description

Primary is nice and bright, and it’s pair is easily split with this scope and EP. Cool blue color in the primary.

item.title: Alpha Ursa Minoris
item.description:
Alpha Ursa Minoris

Star 10 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Alpha Ursa Minoris
Seeing: G
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 130x
Date: 5-11-24
Time: 9:38pm EST
Est. P.A.: 182 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Additional Notes

The seeing really messed with finding the secondary star. Had to measure direction by using the drift method. My est. PA was far off initially. I think it’s because celestial north as more counterclockwise than I thought.

item.title: Mu Bootis
item.description:
Mu Bootis

Star 58 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Mu Bootis
Seeing: G
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 52x
Date: 5-11-24
Time: 10:07pm EST
Est. P.A.: 128 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

This pair looked dim compared to it’s listed magnitude. Both stars are white

Additional Notes

Near some lights tonight; probably contributed to my night vision being affected.

item.title: Nu Draconis
item.description:
Nu Draconis

Star 74 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Nu Draconis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 36.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 144x
Date: 5-2-24
Time: 12:36am EST
Est. P.A.: 300 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

This pair is identical in the EP. Confirmed by looking up the magnitudes! The star to the south looks slightly yellow and the other white.

Additional Notes

The primary was readily identifiable since the pair did not differ in size nor magnitude. Used the yellow southern star as primary.

item.title: 54 Leonis
item.description:
54 Leonis

Star 43 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: 54 Leonis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 36.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 144x
Date: 5-1-24
Time: 11:44pm EST
Est. P.A.: 115 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Small pair, both a little blue in color and sharp in the EP. Easily split.

Additional Notes

Nice showpiece pair for star parties.

item.title: Alpha Geminorum
item.description:
Alpha Geminorum

Star 36 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Alpha Geminorum
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 144x
Date: 5-1-24
Time: 10:08pm EST
Est. P.A.: 45 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The pair are slightly blue, with the secondary being roughly half the size of the primary.

Additional Notes

At this magnification only two stars - very dim - are close by.

item.title: Alpha Leonis
item.description:
Alpha Leonis

Star 41 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Alpha Leonis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 144x
Date: 5-1-24
Time: 11:26pm EST
Est. P.A.: 300 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Primary star is so bright that it almost overpowers it’s secondary. Both appear white in color.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Gamma Leonis
item.description:
Gamma Leonis

Star 42 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Gamma Leonis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 36.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 144x
Date: 5-1-24
Time: 11:33pm EST
Est. P.A.: 112 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Both stars are slightly yellow. Eventhough only a few arc minutes apart I easily split the pair at this power.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Iota Cancri
item.description:
Iota Cancri

Star 39 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Iota Cancri
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 144x
Date: 5-1-24
Time: 11:05pm EST
Est. P.A.: 300 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

A nice pair worth revisiting. At this power, easily split. The primary star is strikingly yellow and the secondary is white.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Eta Persei
item.description:
Eta Persei

Star 12 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Eta Persei
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 130x
Date: 1-4-24
Time: 8:41pm EST
Est. P.A.: 315 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The 34.1" separation made this pair easy to spot. Eta Persei 1 is very golden and bright. It’s secondary in the pair is northwest.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Struve 331
item.description:
Struve 331

Star 13 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Struve 331
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 130x
Date: 1-4-24
Time: 8:22pm EST
Est. P.A.: 90 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Struve 332 2 lies east of the primary at this time. The primary is white with a touch of blue while the secondary is yellow.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Theta 1 Orionis
item.description:
Theta 1 Orionis

Star 23 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Theta 1 Orionis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 144x
Date: 1-4-24
Time: 9:58pm EST
Est. P.A.: (Estimated position angle)

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The four stars of Theta 1 are nice and sharp and bluish white. Partly that color because of the nebula cloud?

Additional Notes

Was initially unsure about which star to calculate PA with. Had to ask the program director how to figure that out when the “double” star contains more than two stars in the group.

item.title: Theta 2 Orionis
item.description:
Theta 2 Orionis

Star 25 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Theta 2 Orionis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 4
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 144x
Date: 1-4-24
Time: 10:06pm EST
Est. P.A.: 90 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Theta 2 falls away from Theta 1 and the nebula. The stars are white and nicely distantfrom each other with good magnitude for viewing.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Beta Orionis
item.description:
Beta Orionis

Star 18 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Beta Orionis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 130x
Date: 12-31-23
Time: 11:40pm EST
Est. P.A.: 200 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Very hard pair to split since Beta 1 is so brightand Beta 2 is so close.

Additional Notes

Only a couple other very faint stars in FOV with this power and scope.

item.title: Delta Orionis
item.description:
Delta Orionis

Star 20 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Delta Orionis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 130x
Date: 12-31-23
Time: 1103:pm Est
Est. P.A.: 0 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Large difference in magnitude between Delta 1 & Delta 2. Delta 2 seems to be pointed directly at north. At most maybe 1 or 2 degrees to the west.

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Iota Orionis
item.description:
Iota Orionis

Star 24 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Iota Orionis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102
Power: 130x
Date: 12-31-23
Time: 11:52pm EST
Est. P.A.: 150 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Main star of the pair is noticeably blue. Split the pair easily.

Additional Notes

Many stars in the surrounding starfield.

item.title: Lambda Orionis
item.description:
Lamda Orionis

Star 22 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Lambda Orionis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.15, -85.32
Instrument: 1300/102 (Orion Apex Maksutov)
Power: 130x
Date: 12-31-23
Time: 11:21pm EST
Est. P.A.: 35 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

The pair are very close in the eyepiece. Their color is the same. Lambda 2 appears about halk the size of Lambda 1, but both are relatively small stars.

item.title: Beta Lyrae
item.description:
Beta Lyrae

Star 81 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Beta Lyrae
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: 750/150 (Orion Starblast 6)
Power: 106x
Date: 7-11-23
Time: 9:46pm EST
Est. P.A.: (Estimated position angle)

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Beta 1 is nice an bright with Beta 2 above and to the left in the EP. Sparse surrounding starfield.

Additional Notes

At the time of observation the sky wasn’t completely dark

item.title: Kappa Herculis
item.description:
Kappa Herculis

Star 64 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Kappa Herculis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 7
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: 750/150 (Orion Starblast 6)
Power: 106x
Date: 7-11-23
Time: 10:59pm EST
Est. P.A.: 20 deg

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Kappa 1 and Kappa 2 are closer together than most I observed so far. They appear slightly smaller too making the difference on magnitude harder to define, but not impossible. Kappa 1 is above. Kappa 2 below and slightly to the left

item.title: Iota Bootis
item.description:
Iota Bootis

Star 52 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Iota Bootis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: 750/150 (Orion Starblast 6)
Power: 53x
Date: 7-10-23
Time: 10:52pm EST
Est. P.A.:

Observation Notes

Visual Description

This pair stands out as the brightest in the eyepiece. The brightest of the pair is on the left.

Additional Notes

Surrounding starfield are all dimmer than the pair.

item.title: Kappa Bootis
item.description:
Kappa Bootis

Star 51 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Kappa Bootis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 6
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: 750/150 (Orion Starblast 6)
Power: 53x
Date: 7-10-2023
Time: 10:33pm EST
Est. P.A.:

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Kappa 1 and Kappa 2 are almost alone in the center of the eyepiece.

Additional Notes

The wide FOV of the EP makes the distances look long.

item.title: 31 Cygni
item.description:
31 Cygni

Star 87 of 100

My Observation Details

Seeing: VG
Transparency: 3
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: 750/150 (Orion Starblast 6)
Power: 75x
Date: 6-28-23
Time: 11:20pm EST
Est. P.A.:

Observation Notes

Visual Description

31 Cygnus A is distinctly orange with it’s companion being a cooler blue. In the sketch the “B” star is above and to the left

Additional Notes

Any other observations, challenges encountered, or notable details about this observation session

item.title: Delta Bootis
item.description:
Delta Bootis

Star 57 of 100

My Observation Details
Object Name: Delta Bootis
Seeing: VG
Transparency: 3
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37
Instrument: 750/150 (Orion Starblast 6)
Power: 75x
Date: 6-28-23
Time: 10:22pm EST
Est. P.A.:

Observation Notes

Visual Description

Delta Bootes is brightest in sketch with its pair above to the right.

Additional Notes

A very faint zig-zag of other stars was visible in eyepiece. Moon is waxing at 78%.

item.title: Alpha Librae

Transparency: 5
Lat/Lon: 35.16, -85.37

Power: 75x
Date: 6-27-23
Time: 9:51pm EST
Est. P.A.: (Estimated position angle)

Visual Description

Epsilon 1 is on the left and Epsilon 2 on the right. Hard to visually see a difference in magnitude.

Additional Notes

Surprised this pair was so far apart even with a 25mm EP
